title: FirstFT: Russia requests military help from China
text:
Russia has asked China for military ​equipment to ​support its invasion of Ukraine, ​according to US officials, sparking concern in ​the White House that Beijing ​may undermine western efforts to help Ukrainian forces defend their country.

US officials told the Financial Times that Russia had requested military equipment and other assistance since the start of the invasion but declined to give details of what aid Russia had requested. Another person familiar with the situation said the US was preparing to warn its allies, amid some indications that China may be preparing to help Russia.

Zhao Lijian, China's foreign ministry spokesperson, dismissed the claims as “disinformation” from the US.

The revelation comes as Jake Sullivan, US national security adviser, heads to Rome for talks today with Yang Jiechi, China's top foreign policy official. The talks are the highest level US-China face-to-face meeting since Russia invaded Ukraine more than three weeks ago and come against a backdrop of rising frustration in the west over China's refusal to condemn the war.

China's state-run media has supported Russian claims that the US was using Ukraine to research dangerous pathogens and biological weapons. China's permanent envoy to the UN on Friday dismissed the US assertion that the biological laboratories allegations were “groundless”. He said that the Russian claims “should be properly addressed”.

Yesterday, China's official state news agency, Xinhua, published a “satellite investigation” that included images of supposed US labs identified by Russia.

More on Ukraine

  • Latest from Ukraine: Russia is continuing its aerial assault on Ukraine's urban centres, including an early morning missile strike on the Obolon district of Kyiv. The latest bombing follow the most deadly attack yet on western Ukraine at a military air base just 10 miles from the border with Nato member Poland.

  • Markets: Russia has threatened to pay international bondholders in roubles rather than dollars just days before a key interest payment on its external debt comes due.

  • Energy: News of a secret meeting between the Biden administration and the authoritarian regime of Nicolás Maduro in Venezuela has triggered a furious backlash among some US lawmakers.

  • Business news: One of the world's highest-grossing law firms, DLA Piper, plans to transfer control of more than 200 staff and offices in Moscow and St Petersburg to local partners in Russia. Europe's largest paint maker, Akzo Nobel, said it expected its operations in Russia to collapse within weeks.

  • At the gateway to Kyiv: Volunteer soldiers prepare to make their stand on battle-scarred suburban streets.

  • Refugee crisis: Poles have launched a huge civic mobilisation as the country struggles to help and house a flood of Ukrainian refugees.

  • Opinion: We need to puncture the Kremlin's alternative reality about the war, writes our editorial board. It is easier for a company to react to the hard edges of a real war than to the nuances of a culture war, writes Andrew Hill.

Follow our live blog and updated maps for the latest on the conflict.

Five more stories in the news

1. Shenzhen locks down 17mn residents The southern Chinese city of Shenzhen has imposed a lockdown as China tries to control the worst outbreak of Covid-19 since the start of the pandemic. Shenzhen-listed stocks dropped 1.2 per cent and Apple supplier Foxconn shut its factories in the city.

2. Ford to expand electric ambitions in Europe The US carmaker is to double investments in Germany, install a battery factory in Turkey and phase out all emissions from its European vans by 2035. The announcements come a week after the group split its businesses into battery-powered vehicles and engine models in a global restructuring to take on electric car pioneer Tesla.

3. Goldman accused of breaching coal pledge with Peabody deal The Wall Street bank is under fire from environmentalists over a $150mn loan to Peabody Energy, the world's biggest private sector coal producer. The deal, arranged to shore up Peabody's derivatives positions, goes against a 2019 pledge by Goldman to only support companies shifting away from coal at a reasonable pace, campaigners say.

4. El Salvador prepares to launch ‘bitcoin bond' The central American country's “bitcoin bond” is set to launch this week. But with institutional investors reluctant to participate and the price of bitcoin in decline, the launch may not be a success.

5. Iran nuclear talks stumble The US has ruled out offering any sanctions relief to Russia in order to clinch Moscow's support for an agreement to revive the 2015 nuclear accord with Iran. Last week Russia demanded guarantees that its trade with Iran would be protected from sanctions as part of any deal, a request the US has rejected.

  • Go deeper: With drought and poor management stifling water supplies, the mood in the Islamic republic has turned to frustration. Tehran correspondent Najmeh Bozorgmehr reports.

The day ahead

Ukraine diplomacy Officials from Ukraine and Russia will hold their fourth round of talks to try and agree a ceasefire in the 18-day war. Volodymyr Zelensky, Ukraine's president, said his representatives were discussing a possible meeting with Russian president Vladimir Putin, as negotiators noted some positive movement on issues of substance in recent days.

Are you involved with training at your organisation? The FT wants to hear from chief learning officers, heads of leadership development and other executives involved in the development of middle and senior managers. Results of the survey will be published in the FT Executive Education report in May 2022.

What else we're reading

SMBC Nikko trading scandal threatens future of its equities division What started as a routine inspection at Japan's SMBC Nikko has evolved into a sprawling investigation that now threatens to sink the brokerage's equities division.

‘Pragmatic' Le Pen re-emerges as main challenger to Macron France is where it was a year ago, with voters likely to have a choice between incumbent Emmanuel Macron and extreme right challenger Marine Le Pen. Such an outcome would repeat the presidential race five years ago. Can Le Pen weather the storm this time?

How private equity firms can resemble the empires they once broke up When GE decided to break itself apart in 2021 many believed this symbolised the demise of the American conglomerate. But as Mark Vandevelde reports, bringing hundreds of companies together under common ownership hasn't died, it has a new name — private equity.

Warwick tops online MBA ranking For the fifth consecutive year, Warwick Business School leads the Financial Times ranking of online MBAs. Alumni salary is again the main factor in its success: an average of $194,864 three years after completion. See the full list here.

The worry of what to wear to work is shifting In the wake of the pandemic, men now face the tyranny of choice that women have suffered for years, writes Pilita Clark. Having discovered the pleasures of the polo shirt at home, many wonder if they really have to gussy up in a suit and tie again.

Travel

The inaugural Marrakesh International Storytelling Festival, a week-long event in Morocco, has emerged as a silver lining from the difficult past two years of pandemic living.
